info.p: These macros may be used anywhere in the script. They can be used to alter how the map is generated based on game settings or random chance.

Macros are distinct from commands as they are interpreted in a preprocessing step before the commands and attributes are parsed. For instance, the following code exists in my installation under: ./.../gamedata_x2/GeneratingObjects.inc
info.code-block: if GNR_PALISADING create_object PALISADE_WALL else create_object STONE_WALL endif { set_place_for_every_player min_distance_to_players 35 max_distance_to_players 35 }
info.p:
In this example, the
macro construct is used to paste together a single final
command from parts. The
command is not read until after the
construct is fully resolved.

This example results in more readable code than introducing two new const declarations with the ids that
and
already represent.

Used to introduce conditions into your map script. These conditions can be based on game settings or previous
statements included in your script.
The following example uses two if-constructs to make the size and terrain of a central lake adapt to the game settings.

ul.li: If the map is huge or larger, the lake will generate with twice as many tiles.
If the game mode is King of the Hill, the lake will be shallows instead of water to allow access to the monument.

info.code-block:
if HUGE_MAP #define LARGE_LAKE elseif GIGANTIC_MAP #define LARGE_LAKE elseif LUDIKRIS_MAP #define LARGE_LAKE else /* default: NORMAL_LAKE */ endif
create_land { if LARGE_LAKE number_of_tiles 3000 else number_of_tiles 1500 endif
base_size 9 clumping_factor 99 land_position 50 50
if KING_OT_HILL terrain_type SHALLOW else terrain_type WATER endif }
info.p: A "not" can be implemented with an if-else where you leave the if clause empty:
info.code-block: if KING_OT_HILL else /* This land is only created if the game mode is NOT King of the hill. */ create_land { ... } endif

info.p: Used to introduce randomly varying features into your map. This could be used to adjust what types of terrain generate to simulate seasons, or to enable or disable the generation of entire features.
The following example is used to generate a random number of relics so that the players will not know exactly how many are present on the map.
info.code-block: create_object RELIC { terrain_to_place_on GRASS temp_min_distance_group_placement 30 start_random percent_chance 25 number_of_objects 2 percent_chance 25 number_of_objects 3 percent_chance 25 number_of_objects 4 percent_chance 25 number_of_objects 5 end_random }
info.p: If percents don't add up to 100, the difference is the percent chance that none of the other options happen.
Starting in Defninitive Edition, this useage of this construct can be replaced with the following shorthand:
While this is useful, there are still many use-cases of the old random construct style that can not be replaced with the new macro.

While a string exists for this macro in the game's data, it is not clear how or if it works. This is likely intended to reverse the effect of a
macro, but it does not appear to function.
The numerical Id of the terrain or object you are giving name to.
While the same Id can be assigned to multiple constant names, any given constant name can only be defined once. Any future definition will be ignored.
This is used in built in map scripts to copy instructions from other files. It can not be used in custom random map scripts.
This appears to refer to the target resource/file name's entry in the strings table, but it is not always used.
This is used in built in map scripts to copy instructions from other files. It can not be used in custom random map scripts.
Players will be positioned randomly.
Players will be positioned in close proximity to their teammates.

Players must be assigned to positioned lands using
and .
Adds the cost of a town center to all players' starting resources.
One of the predefined map type constants.
Indicates to the Ai whether the map has nomad starts or not.
Indicates to the Ai whether the map has michi starts or not.
When set, the map type will be shown in objectives.
Specifies which terrain to use to initially fill the map.
When set to , the new wave effects will be used.
This attribute allows map designers to disable waves on maps where they do not match the aesthetic.
Creates a land for every player.
If you do not place player lands, the game will spawn a town center and villagers for them randomly. You will be unable to spawn resources for these randomly placed town centers.

You may alternatively use the
attribute inside of a
command to create lands for players individually.
Creates a single land.
The land will be neutral by default, but that can be changed via attributes.
Defines the base terrain type to use for this land.
Defines what percentage of the total map area should be used for this land.
If used inside of , this percentage is shared among all player lands.
Defines a fixed size for the land in tiles.

If used inside of , each player land will be sized to
tiles. This is in contrast to
where player lands *share* the defined area.
Defines a minimum radius for the land, counting out from the center tile.
For example, base_size 3 would define a land that is minimally 7x7.
Defines the base elevation for the land.

If used, an
section must be present.
Defines how close to the edge of the map a land can spread.

Negative values may be useful in conjunction with
to encourage lands to spread closer to the edge of the map. If a negative border is specified and
is not used, the game may crash if the land origin is placed outside of the map.
Note: Using this attribute with player lands is buggy in some versions of the game.

syntax.name: land_position

info.p: Defines a fixed origin for the land in terms of a percent of the total width and height of the map.

As of DE, this attribute may be used in conjunction with
so long as
is specified in the <PLAYER_SETUP> section. This was not possible in previous versions.

syntax.note: Placing lands outside of the map will crash the game.

info.p: Defines how relaxed/strict the borders are for this land. At 0, the borders are ignored. At 100, the land can not exceed its borders at all.
Higher values here will cause lands to prefer to spread to tiles closer to their origin, creating rounder lands.

Think of this value as a rating of how much the algorithm should prefer to spread onto a tile close to the origin of the land. Giving a negative value will encourage the algorithm to avoid tiles near the land's origin, creating snake-like lands.
Define an explicit zone for this terrain.
Note: Using zone 99 may crash the game.
Define an random zone for this terrain. This is used in maps like Archipelago to allow players to randomly spawn together or apart.
Sets a zone for players based on their team. Allies will share the same land.
Defines a minimum distance from lands of other zones.
This attribute only works if it is declared in both zones. If you give two lands different values, the smaller avoidance distance will be the one that applies
Specifies the minimum distance that a land's origin must be placed away from the origins of other lands.
Has no effect when used on player lands.

Specified a land id number that can be used to target this land in the
phase.
This will not work with lands created via , but it will work with lands that are made into player lands with .
When multiple lands have the same id, create_object commands will create duplicate objects across all such lands.
Assigns this land to be a player land for the given player. If the player is not playing, the land will not be placed. Lands may only be assigned to a single player.
When used with , player lands can be placed in fixed locations with .
When set, the radius at which players are placed can vary by this amount.
When used in , positions the players in a circle with the given radius.
Contrary to documentation posted to the Forgotten Realms website, the attribute is not implemented and is not needed.
The max elevation to be generated by this command.

Hills may not reach
if their base is too small to support it.
Specifies which terrain hills can grow on.
The total number of tiles to share between all hills generated by this command.
The maximum number of discrete hills to generate.
scales number_of_tiles by the map size scaling factor.
scales number_of_clumps by the map size scaling factor.
Defines the spacing between elevation levels in tiles.
Random map scripts are given very little control over the generation of cliffs. The commands described below apply to all cliffs for the generated map.
Cliffs can not be defined by land or by terrain. They will always avoid the center of a land, player or otherwise. This behavior can not be disabled or modified.
Including a <CLIFF_GENERATION> section with no commands will generate cliffs according to the command defaults.

argument.name: N
argument.info: Note that length is given in cliff sections, not tiles.

argument.name: N
argument.info: Note that length is given in cliff sections, not tiles.

info.p: Defines the terrain type that will be created.
Sets a specific color correction based on the season. Must be one of: CC_DESERT, CC_JUNGLE, CC_AUTUMN, or CC_WINTER.
Defines the terrain type that this terrain should replace.

syntax.name: base_layer

info.p: Defines the masking terrain type that this terrain should replace.
In this example, a portion of the terrain masked with SNOW by the first command is replaced with DESERT.

syntax.note: This entry is based on research done by Zetnus.

info.p: When neither nor are defined, is assumed using the default tile count.
Higher values here will cause clumps to prefer to spread to tiles closer to their origin, creating rounder areas.

Allows the terrain to be placed as an overlay or underlay of the existing terrain, rather than replacing it entirely. This can create unique visuals that were not possible in previous versions of the game.
Connections will be routed between the origins of all lands.
This common example ensures all lands are connected by shallows.
Connections will be routed between the origins of all player lands.

syntax.name: create_connect_teams_lands
syntax.info: Connections will be routed between the origins of player lands and the lands of their teammates.

info.p: This command is undocumented and appears to function the same as .

syntax.name: create_connect_to_nonplayer_land
syntax.info: Connections will be routed from each player land to all non-player lands. If there is a single central non-player land, this allows the creation of a spoked hub.
syntax.note: This command is currently bugged. It blocks any other connections from being created.

argument.name: REPLACEMENT_TYPE
argument.info: The terrain to replace it with.

info.p: Defines a terrain replacement to use while routing a connection. This attribute may be used multiple times in a given command to define multiple replacement relationships.
When specified, any terrain that does not have an explicit attribute will be replaced with the terrain given here.
The cost of routing a connection through terrain of type .
This attribute may be used multiple times in a given command.
Defines the width of the path through terrain of the given type. If is greater or equal to the path may be broken when its size hits zero.
When creating the VILLAGER object, the default changes to the correct number of starting villagers for that civilization.

Sets the number of objects to generate, or the number of objects in each group if
is not 1.
When specified, objects placed with will be assigned to the gaia faction.
This attribute is required for most resource objects.

syntax.name: terrain_to_place_on
syntax.info: Specifies which single type of terrain the objects may be placed on.

info.p: When is specified, this constraint applies only to the player the object is placed for.
When is not specified, this constraint applies to the origin of all lands, not just player lands.
When is specified, this constraint applies to the distance to that land's origin.
When is specified, this constraint applies to the player the object is placed for.
When is specified, this constraint applies to the distance to that land's origin.
Contrary to what its name implies, this attribute specifies a minimum distance to the edge of the zone the object is placed in.
Constrains the placement of this and all future objects so that no object (or no origin of a group of objects) will exist within tiles of this object.
Higher values tend to place hard constraints on the spawning of other objects.
Constrains the placement of objects for this command only so that no two objects (or groups of objects) are placed within tiles of eachother.
Defines the radius from the origin of a group of objects in which objects can be placed.
The radius does not include the origin tile, so a radius of 3 defines a 7x7 square region.

syntax.name: set_tight_grouping
syntax.info: When specified, objects in a group will be generated without any space in between them.

info.p: When specified, objects in a group may have space in between them.
This attribute is the default in the absence of a attribute, so it may be omitted.
Causes the object to be placed on the specified land.
Causes an object to contain more or less of a collectable resource.
Causes a second object to be placed at the same location. This is used by built-in scripts to place farms under villagers.
This has some limited use in composing eye candy objects, but is otherwise mostly useless.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.
Objects will be placed at least tiles away from a forest zone.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.
Objects will be placed at least tiles away from a cliff zone.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.

This new attribute was announced and documented on the
Forgotten Empires website.
The following commands/attributes have strings present in the game data, but do not seem to be implemented and are not used by the built-in map scripts.
While the data in this section is primarily intended to be read by another program, it is presented in this formatted output for your reference.
This data set contains a record for every possible map type, along with the edge dimension (size), area, and scaling ratio for each type.
Note that the constant is actually what the game refers to as a "Normal" sized map and the constant refers to what the game calls a "Large" map.

record.name: RMS Tokens

info.p: These tokens are taken from the strings file in AoE II: DE's game data. Some, such as , are syntax that are functional in userpatch but do not seem to work in Definitive Edition.

record.values:
#define #undefine #const if elseif else endif start_random percent_chance end_random #include #include_drs <PLAYER_SETUP> <LAND_GENERATION> <CLIFF_GENERATION> <TERRAIN_GENERATION> <OBJECTS_GENERATION> <CONNECTION_GENERATION> <ELEVATION_GENERATION> random_placement grouped_by_team nomad_resources ai_info_map_type create_player_lands create_land enable_waves color_correction create_terrain create_elevation min_number_of_cliffs max_number_of_cliffs min_length_of_cliff max_length_of_cliff cliff_curliness min_distance_cliffs min_terrain_distance create_object create_connect_all_players_land create_connect_teams_lands create_connect_same_land_zones create_connect_all_lands create_connect_to_nonplayer_land guard_state
base_terrain> base_terrain
min_distance max_distance set_position land_percent terrain_type base_size left_border right_border top_border bottom_border border_fuzziness zone set_zone_by_team set_zone_randomly other_zone_avoidance_distance assign_to_player percent_of_land number_of_clumps spacing_to_other_terrain_types set_scaling_to_map_size number_of_groups number_of_objects group_variance group_placement_radius set_loose_grouping set_tight_grouping terrain_to_place_on set_gaia_object_only set_place_for_every_player place_on_specific_land_id min_distance_to_players max_distance_to_players land_position land_id clumping_factor number_of_tiles set_scale_by_groups set_scale_by_size set_avoid_player_start_areas min_distance_group_placement spacing default_terrain_replacement replace_terrain terrain_cost terrain_size min_placement_distance set_scaling_to_player_number height_limits set_flat_terrain_only max_distance_to_other_zones temp_min_distance_group_placement base_elevation direct_placement resource_delta assign_to terrain_mask circle_radius base_layer place_on_forest_zone avoid_forest_zone find_closest actor_area actor_area_radius actor_area_to_place_in avoid_actor_area avoid_all_actor_areas layer_to_place_on force_placement second_object
